results.title: Flemingdon Park: the global village
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gerry Flahive and Andrew Faiz
results.brief_description: A trendy urban development in Toronto for professionals and artists turned subsidized housing which attracted thousands of refugees and new immigrants, Flemingdon Park has become known as a multicultural model for urban planning. This documentary discusses the past and present community of Flemingdon Park, as well as the challenges the diverse residents face and the valuable lessons offered by the community that has developed there. From a history of overcoming violence and racism to the hope of the celebration of difference in increasingly inclusive and welcoming community attitudes there are many and varied facets to life in and around the Park. Many of these elements are touched on in this program in order to come to terms with the history and current experience of the community through interviews with past and present residents, teachers and students from neighbouring schools, the Park’s designer and architect and through commentary from journalist Robert Fulford and the documentary’s director, Andrew Faiz, himself a former resident.

results.title: Flax
results.brief_description: Opens with scenes of the flax industry in pre-war Ireland. With the outbreak of war, Britain’s supply of European flax was cut off. The film shows various improvements adopted to increase the production of flax in Britain, including the use of machines to pull the fibre and also the use of material in the unretted state.

results.title: Flatland
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films, Harvard University and Edwin Abbot
results.brief_description: An animated mathematical allegory by Edwin Abbot about a square who discovers the third dimension, but is jailed by the two-dimensional inhabitants of Flatland when he preaches multidimensionality. Also offers a universal social commentary on social structures and values. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: Flat
results.brief_description: Carried out in a 2D reality, repetitive motions mirror the mechanical patterns in modern society. In this one-shot abstracted sequence, abscuring motion and direction, repeated gestures move beyond meaning and into compulsive necessity. Detail magnifies while reason fades.

results.title: Flashpoint
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Don Worobey and Ernie Schmidt
results.brief_description: An animated interpretation of the Pacific Ocean ablaze as a result of a collision between two giant supertankers. The film explains that there is no technology available to cope with such a disaster, and in a realistic, animated way it is a reminder of the dangers of tanker traffic in coastal waters. The stunning animation method used in this short film is similar to Japanese ‘Manga’ style. Although this film deals with serious issues surrounding environmental disasters, it manages to introduce some comic moments that simultaneously educate and entertain. Story by Ian Slater. Animation by Ernie Schmidt.

results.title: Flashdance
results.creator_credit: PolyGram, Paramount Pictures, Don Simpson, Jerry Bruckheimer and Adrian Lyne
results.brief_description: Flashdance is the story of Alex Owens, a fiercely determined 18 year old who is a Pittsburgh steel-mill welder by day, and a bar dancer by night. We follow her struggle to gain independence, find love, and to realise her dream for a career in modern dance. Includes music by Giorgio Moroder. Cast includes Jennifer Beals, Michael Nouri, Lilia Skala, Sunny Johnson and Kyle Heffner.

results.title: Flash William
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Arthur Hammond, Michael McKennirey, Thom Burstyn and John Laing
results.brief_description: Flash William Shewchuck is a one-man movie industry. He combines the roles of film producer, director, camera man, actor, promoter, projectionist and ticket taker. In between productions, he works elsewhere to finance his company. In this film about his latest feature, “Dawson City Joe”, he reveals his style and technique. Some of his innovations, developed by Flash in the isolation of the wilderness, have long been used in the industry. Voice and narration by Stanley Jackson.

results.title: Flash point
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Gil Brealey and Brian Hannant
results.brief_description: A drama set in the remote outback northwestern mining town of Mount Newman where men outnumber women fifty to one. Provides a study of mateship, of human relationships against the background of Australia’s mineral development. An interesting study of the tensions, and the loneliness that exists in such a remote mining town.

results.title: Flash Gordon. Vol. 02
results.brief_description: Episodes 7 to 13 of this cult movie serial. Episode 7: “Shattering Doom”: In this episode, Flash is tortured and Dale is forced to betray him. He is sent back to the atom furnaces with the order that high voltage wire be connected to his wrist. Episode 8: “Tournament of Death”: Ming arrives in Vultan’s kingdom and Flash fights to earn his freedom in combat with a masked gladiator and a huge orangopoid. Episode 9: “Fighting the Fire Dragon”: Conspiring with Princess Aura, the High Priest gives Flash drops of forgetfulness and has him sent through the Tunnel of Terror to the abode of the sacred Fire Dragon. Episode 10: “The Unseen Peril”: Brought before Ming to choose his bride and unable to remember Dale, Flash goes off with Aura, but is rescued by Zarkov, Dale and Barin. Episode 11: “In the Claws of the Tigron”: Using Zarkov’s invisibility machine Flash releases Vultan from his dungeon prison and rushes to rescue Dale from the claws of the vicious tigron. Episode 12: “Trapped in the Turret”: In this episode Vultan invites Flash and his friends to visit his sky city. Episode 13: “Rocketing to Earth”: In the thirteenth and final episode Flash and his friends take refuge in Zharkov’s laboratory and prepare to leave Mongo for earth.
